**Title:** *Commentary on the Yellow Emperor’s* **Yin Fu Jing** *(Obscure Classic)*

**Author:** *Commentary on the Yellow Emperor’s* **Yin Fu Jing** *by Tang Chun (唐淳), compiled in the* **Jingyi (己丑)** *year of the reign* **Zhengda (正大)** *of Emperor Aizong of Jin (金哀宗). Two volumes. Source text:* **Zhengtong Daozang (正统道藏)***, Treasure of the Cavern of Perfection (洞真部), Jade Precepts (玉诀类).*

**Preface to the Commentary on the Yellow Emperor’s* **Yin Fu Jing** *

Only those who penetrate the profound mysteries of the heavens can elucidate the subtleties of the **Dao/Way**. How could one who has not yet attained the realm of the sages interpret the sages’ scriptures?

Why so? The sages’ words are vast as the heavens—how could those who do not delve into enigmas and unravel hidden meanings ever grasp them?

Take, for instance, the Yellow Emperor’s *Yin Fu Jing*—its chapters are but one or two, its text scarcely three hundred words. Though concise in expression, its meaning is profound and distant; though simple in form, its intent is boundless and intricate.

Some may take it as a method for enriching the state and securing the people, others as a strategy for strengthening armies and achieving victory. It encompasses all of heaven and earth, synthesizes the principles of **yin and yang**, yet appears without form or sound—so subtle that one can intuitively perceive its essence, yet so elusive that its depths cannot be fully plumbed.

Unless one’s inner and outer self is clear and unobstructed, one’s surface and depths polished and refined, unless one can grasp the **Dao/Way** of heaven and earth and command the interplay of **yin and yang**, who could first dissect and then annotate it?

Yet many have commented on this text, but only Master Tang has truly captured the sages’ subtle intent.

Master Tang’s given name was **Chun (淳)**, and he styled himself the **Jinling Daoist (金陵道人)**. His origins remain unknown.

Thus, he expounded what he had heard, aligned with the sages’ intent, and supplemented with references from other works to verify it. For those who come after, when they read the original text, they may find its profundity and remoteness daunting—but when they consult his commentary, they will discover its clarity and accessibility.

Each word he elucidates is like a lamp dispelling darkness; each phrase he interprets is like a tortoise shell divining doubt.

Had Master Tang not inherently known the source of all existence, had he not deeply explored the origins of **creation/transformation (造化)**, had he not penetrated the **Dao/Way’s** mysteries and entered the sages’ realm, how could he have achieved this?

In recent times, **Yingran Zi (莹然子)**—a disciple of **Zhou Zhiming (周至明)**—has emerged, a scholar of our age. Inspired by the Yellow Emperor’s legends while visiting the **Kongtong Mountains (崆峒)**, he was moved by a desire to preserve and refine the **Dao/Way**, and thus sought this annotated text to engrave and print it.

May practitioners of the **Dao/Way** thereby discern the true from the false, attain sainthood while remaining in the mortal realm, hold **yin and yang** in their palms, and encompass the sun and moon within their chests—truly embodying the sages’ original purpose.

He requested I write a preface, and though I wished to decline, I feared the sin of not praising a worthy friend.

Thus, I took up my brush and composed this, merely to honor Master Tang’s noble endeavor.

Written in the **Jingyi (己丑)** year of **Zhengda (正大)**, at **Huoze (濩泽)**, by **Meng Shao (孟绰)**.

**Commentary on the Yellow Emperor’s* **Yin Fu Jing** *, Volume One*
*Annotated by Jinling Daoist Tang Chun (金陵道人 唐淳注)*

「The *Bao Yi* Chapter on the Dao/Way of the Immortals and Divine Ones
The divine, when in the eyes, is vision;
when in the ears, is hearing;
when in the tongue, is speech;
when in the nose, perceives fragrance;
when in the hands, manifests as clenched fists;
when in the feet, becomes movement.

By day, it takes form as thought;
by night, as dreams.
When summoned, it comes;
when dismissed, it departs.
In the mind, it is will;
in speech, it is eloquence.

Between formlessness, it gathers and scatters without trace.
Within, it becomes emotional states;
without, it dissolves into emptiness.
When scattered, it permeates the cosmos and the Nine Barbarians—nowhere is untouched.
When concealed, it enters even minute dust particles and sesame seeds.

It resides in the **elixir field (Dan Tian)**, and when cultivated, one becomes an immortal.

If one is dull and confused, the excess becomes a lower ghost.
Scattered, it is the mind;
gathered, it is the **qi**.
When **qi** moves, the divine moves;
when **qi** gathers, the divine gathers.

The *Yijing (I Ching)* says: *"The unfathomable interplay of yin and yang is called the divine."*

It further states: *"The divine dwells in the elixir field; the **qi** condenses into an embryo."*
True **qi** does not disperse,
the divine and luminous naturally arise.
Thus, the divine and **qi** mutually uphold one another—
is this not the Dao/Way of longevity?

The divine is the child of **qi**,
**qi** is the mother of the divine.
The *Dao De Jing (Laozi’s Classic of the Dao)* says: *"Knowing its child, yet preserving its mother."*

Tang Chun says: *"The mutual preservation of child and mother is the Dao/Way of the immortals."*

Master Shi Zhenren says: *"If divine and **qi** do not disperse,
one is naturally a longevity cultivator."*

The term *immortal (xian)* means *transcendence*.
Common folk call those who attain the Dao/Way *immortals*,
where the character *xian* (仙) is *ren* (人) beside *shan* (山, mountain).
When common folk refine themselves,
their nature is like mountains and rivers—
their divine **qi** undisturbed and unshaken,
thus, *ren* beside *shan* also.

The terms *immortals and divine ones (shenxian)* are titles for those who have attained the Dao/Way.
Just as people call others *郎 (lang)*—
a term for those with wealth and status—
*immortals* refers to those who have cultivated the Dao/Way and embraced the treasures within.

*Bao* (抱) means *to embrace and conceal*.
*Yi* (一) signifies the *Dao/Way*.
Thus, the chapter *"Bao Yi"* is indeed the beginning of the exposition on the Dao/Way.

To observe the Dao/Way of Heaven,
and to grasp Heaven’s operations—
that is all.

*Observe (guan)* means *to contemplate*,
with the upper tone as *guan* (官, official) and the lower as *guan* (贯, pierce).
To look upward is to observe;
to look downward is to observe.
*Observe* refers to the contemplation of the Six Gates.

The Buddhist school says: *"To internalize the external forms and return them to the mind is called contemplation (guanxiang)."*
Thus, it is called the *locking of the Six Gates*—
within, nothing escapes;
without, nothing enters—
this is the method of *guanxing*.

To look upward is to observe;
*Observe* means *to perceive*.
To perceive the Dao/Way of Heaven,
the **North Dipper (Bei Dou)** aligns directly below,
the **True One of the Supreme Unity (Tai Yi Zhen Jun)** is the **qi** of Heaven—
its name is **Tai Yi** (太一).

The **Yin True One (Yin Zhen Jun)** says: *"Tai Yi contains the true **qi**."*

Common texts state:
*"To store it is the **original essence (Yuan Jing)**;
to apply it is **vitality (Wan Ling)**;
to contain it is **Tai Yi**;
to release it is **Tai Qing (太清)**."*

When **Tai Yi** descends directly,
the **True One (Zhen Yi)** operates;
when **Tai Yi** ascends directly,
the **North Dipper** aligns with its symbols.

The **Dipper (Dou)** is the handle;
merely observe the **North Dipper’s** monthly stations—
the Dao/Way of Heaven observed in the first month’s station,
the **Tiger (Yin)** in the **Tiger** month—
cycling endlessly without cessation.

One **qi** ascends and descends,
the sun and moon revolve;
the **Five Stars** and **Six Celestial Lights (Liu Yao)**,
arranged in myriad forms—
all operate in harmony.

Thus it is said:
*"Five days mark a **host (hou)**,
fifteen days mark a **qi**,
forty-five days mark a **node (jie)**,
ninety days mark a **season (ji)**."*

Spring generates, summer lengthens,
autumn harvests, winter stores.
It gives rise to all things—
Heaven above, Heaven below,
palaces of the immortals, realm of mortals,
embryos, eggs, damp transformations—
one root, one sprout,
one branch, one leaf,
one blossom, one fruit—
sentient and insentient alike,
all receive the **Dao/Way’s qi** and are thereby produced.

Thus, all things within and without are none other than the Dao/Way itself.
Therefore, when one perceives the Dao/Way of Heaven’s operations,
one also observes that human cultivation does not differ from Heaven’s Dao/Way.

The Dao/Way of humanity:
**Tai Yi** resides between the two kidneys,
with a yellow center in the hall,
red above and black below,
blue-green to the left and white to the right—
its embrace of the Five Phases,
the **Supreme Unity (Hun Yuan Yi)**,
the **True One (Zhen Yi)**,
is called **Tai Yi**.

**Tai Yi** is the sovereign name of **water**.
The **North Dipper’s** alignment is the **seven orifices of the heart (Xin Qi Qiao)**.
The sun and moon are the **heart and kidneys**.
Humans without sun and moon,
use the heart and kidneys as sun and moon;
Heaven without heart and kidneys,
uses the sun and moon as heart and kidneys.

The **Five Stars** and **Six Celestial Lights** correspond to the **Five Zang Organs** and **Six Fu Organs**.
The *"myriad forms"* are the **36,000 divine lights** of skin, hair, bones, and joints.

The *Dao De Jing* says: *"Without leaving one’s door, one knows the affairs of the world."*
Master He Shang Gong says: *"The human body is likened to Heaven and Earth’s operations."*

Moreover, when one aligns their own **Tai Yi** with its celestial movement,
the sun and moon revolve in harmony,
and the true essence is attained.

When the **heart’s fire** descends and the **kidney’s water** ascends,
water above and fire below,
the **Five Zang Organs** and **hundred meridians** produce **vital fluids (jin ye)**.
The **qi**, **vital fluids**, **blood**, and **divine lights** flow naturally,
the **Five Phases**, **Four Symbols**, **Eight Trigrams**, and **myriad divine essences** return to the Great Dao/Way.
The **hundred bones** and **nine orifices** attain **spiritual responsiveness (Tong Ling)**,
the hands grasp **Tai Yi**,
and **life and vitality are secured**.

If one follows the Dao/Way of Heaven’s operations,
will they not live as long as Heaven and Earth?
Thus it is said: *"To grasp Heaven’s operations—
that is all."*

Therefore, the sages point to Heaven’s Dao/Way,
and liken human cultivation to observing Heaven’s operations.
To grasp Heaven’s operations,
there is none who does not become an immortal.

Heaven has **Five Thieves (Wu Ze)**;
those who perceive them flourish.
To obtain the thieves is to flourish;
to lose them is to perish.

The **Seven Worthies (Qi Xian)** say:
*"The Five Stars, Five Mountains, Five Zang Organs, Five Directions, and Five Thieves—
these are the Five Thieves’ alignment with the Five Phases,
a treasure held by the profound scholars,
all-encompassing in meaning."*

Tang Chun says:
*"Heaven and Earth employ the Five Phases,
each alternately restraining and generating the others.
Heaven’s Five Thieves are:
**wood, water, metal, earth, and fire**;
Earth’s Five Thieves are:
**metal, wood, water, fire, and earth**.

The sages say that Heaven’s Five Thieves move in reverse,
yin and yang inverted and returning;
Earth’s Five Thieves follow Earth’s natural order,
thus humans have life and death.

If one perceives Heaven’s thieves,
and operates in accordance with them,
then humans have only life and no death.

Thus it is said: *"Those who perceive them flourish."*

Moreover, when observing Earth’s Five Phases,
**metal** generates **water**—
but Heaven’s Five Phases are otherwise,
for **water** generates **metal** instead.»

When observing **water-qi** ascending as vapor,
transforming into clouds in the sky—
since Heaven belongs to **metal**,
and cloud-qi ascends to Heaven,
it is said: *"Water comes to generate **metal**."*

Son perceives Mother, manifesting its original form,
and becomes rain.

The *Classic of Changes* says:
*"Clouds move and rain is bestowed,
all things flourish in their forms."*

This is the **Dao/Way of Heaven** moving in reverse.

Moreover, when observing Earth’s Five Phases,
**wood** generates **fire**—
but Heaven’s Five Phases are otherwise,
for **fire** generates **wood** instead.

In humans, this is **qi**; in Heaven, it is the **Great Sun**.
When **true-qi** gives rise to all things,
it is **yang-qi** entering **wood**,
causing branches and leaves to sprout,
perfuming and nourishing all things—
even stones and wood flourish.

Thus it is said: *"Fire generates **wood**."*
Is this not the **Dao/Way of Heaven**?

Therefore, the sages point to Heaven’s **Dao/Way**,
urging people to embody Heaven’s laws.
If one does not act in reverse,
they will not attain longevity.
To achieve longevity, one must practice inverted methods.

What is the method of inverted Five Phases?
Take the **heart-fire** arising from **kidney-water**—
when **water** perceives **fire**, it transforms into **qi**,
and this **qi** ascends to the **lungs**,
since the **lungs** belong to **metal**—
this is **water** generating **metal**.

The **water** then transforms into **golden liquid**,
which enters the **liver**.
The **liver** is **wood**; the **heart** is **fire**.
When **fire** comes to generate **wood**,
the **liver** flourishes, and the eyes shine brightly,
their black and white clearly distinct.

**Wood** takes on the nature of **fire**,
**metal** takes on the essence of **water**—
the **Southern Fire** generates the **Eastern Wood**,
the **Northern Water** generates the **Western Metal**.

The **Four Symbols** and **Two Principles** are further combined with the **Steel-and-Water Earth** (戊己土), hence it is said that the **Five Phases do not proceed in order**, and when the **Four Symbols** merge into the **Central Palace**, it is called the **Method of Inverted Five Phases**.

The **True Master Taibai** said:
*The Method of Inverted Five Phases*—
the **Dragon emerges from fire**.

*The Five Phases do not proceed in order*—
the **Tiger is born in water**.

The **True One Son** said:
These twenty characters—
few in number yet profound in meaning—
are called **revealing the mutual interplay of Heaven and Earth**.

The **Yin True Lord** said:
The **true qi of the North** is called the **River Vehicle**,
while the **East’s Jia-Yi** forms **golden sand**.
The **Vermilion Bird** regulates its movement to generate **golden splendor**,
and **golden splendor** produces the **Heaven-Earth Treasure**.

If one comprehends these words,
harmonizing **inner and outer Dao**,
aligning with the **Heaven-Earth Way**,
and refining essence into **spiritual elixir**,
then **transmuting the Four Great Elements**,
one may ascend lightly—
is this not the **Dao of Immortals and Transcendents**?
Thus it is said:
*Those who perceive this flourish.*

The **Five Bandits** reside in the heart,
and their influence extends to Heaven.
The **Five Bandits** in the heart—
these are the **true qi of the Five Phases**.
With the heart as sovereign,
movement stirs the Five Phases in response.
Thus it is said:
*The Five Bandits reside in the heart.*

When their influence extends to Heaven,
one must align with the **Heavenly Dao**,
for all good and evil originate from the heart.
All actions must conform to Heaven’s **Way**,
and when the heart acts,
it harmonizes with the **Five Bandits of Heaven** in their operations.

The **universe lies within the hand**,
and **ten thousand transformations arise from the body**.
The **universe lies within the hand**,
and **ten thousand transformations arise from the body**—
this is where **Immortal cultivation begins**,
the **craft of sages and worthies**,
the **authority of yin and yang**.

Yin and yang—
these are **Sun and Moon**.
The **Sun is the Dragon**,
the **Moon is the Tiger**;
the **Sun is Mercury**,
the **Moon is Lead**;
the **Sun is Li**,
the **Moon is Kan**;
the **Sun is Fire**,
the **Moon is Water**;
the **Sun is the yang soul**,
the **Moon is the yin spirit**;
the **Sun is qi**,
the **Moon is essence**;
the **Sun is nature**,
the **Moon is fate**.

He who grasps the universe
holds **life and death in his hand**.
My fate lies within me,
not in Heaven—
in Heaven, it is the **Sun and Moon**;
in man, it is **essence and qi**.
Heaven moves by the **Sun and Moon’s revolution**,
while man moves by the **circulation of essence and qi**.

The **True Master Lü** said:
When someone asked me of the **cultivation method**,
I pointed to the **Sun and Moon’s wheel** in the sky.

**Wei Boyang’s** *Parametric Contract* sings:
*The Sage seizes the intent of Creation,*
*supporting Sun and Moon within the furnace.*
*Subtly reversing Heaven-Earth’s essence,*
*drilling through yin and yang to command spirits.*
*If one recognizes the Sun’s soul and Moon’s spirit,*
*the knower is a child of the Immortals.*
*Refine and ingest for a thousand days—*
*when the body lacks no yin, how can death come?*

The *Plain Questions* [□] *On Ancient Celestial Truth* says:
*I have heard that the ancient True Ones upheld Heaven and Earth,*
*grasped yin and yang,*
*inhaled essence-qi,*
*stood alone guarding the spirit,*
*their flesh and muscles unified—*
*thus they could live as long as Heaven and Earth,*
*without beginning or end.*

Zhang Menggan said:
*Containing Heaven and Earth in the palm,*
*gathering and dispersing the Three Celestial Lights;*
*holding Sun and Moon at the chest,*
*rolling and unfolding the Eight Scenes.*

The *Dao De Jing* says:
*Deep roots and firm foundations—*
*the Dao of eternal life and longevity.*

The **Sun and Moon reside in heart and kidney**,
the **heart is prone to movement**,
the **spirit prone to leaking essence**.
Thus the **Sage restrains the heart from moving**,
grasp the **kidney to prevent leakage**—
when firm and unbroken,
the body becomes light,
and thus **eternal life and longevity** are attained.
Is this not the **starting point of Immortal cultivation**,
where **heart and kidney interact**,
**essence and qi reverse**,
and **ten thousand transformations arise from the body**?

Thus it is said:
*The mechanisms of Immortal transformation—*
*to turn ghosts into Immortals,*
*to revive the dead as the living—*
*this is the universe within the hand.*

When **Heaven unleashes the killing intent**,
**dragons and serpents rise from the earth**.

This is the **inner alchemy of the Three Hundred Characters**—
**Heaven’s nature** is **humanity**;
**human heart** is the **mechanism**.
Establishing **Heaven’s Way** to **determine humanity**.
These sixteen characters were added by **Du Guangting**.

Chun said:
When **Heaven unleashes the killing intent**,
it is the **third month of autumn**,
when the **West’s metal-qi** brings frost,
capable of killing all things.
Metal can overcome wood,
so dragons and serpents retreat underground,
and all things may be killed.
The *Dao De Jing* says:
*Heaven and Earth are not kind—they treat all things as sacrificial dogs.*

**Dragons and serpents rising from the earth**—
this is the **third month of spring**,
when all things sprout,
and Heaven-Earth renew.
Autumn kills, spring generates—
this is the **principle of the Way**.
Spring is the **Tai co-ordinate**,
autumn is the **Pi co-ordinate**—
spring generates, autumn kills—
this is the **meaning of Heaven-Earth’s reversal**.

When **humanity unleashes the killing intent**,
**Heaven and Earth reverse**.
The greatest **human killing intent** is **filial disobedience**,
a crime without pardon,
hence **Heaven and Earth reverse**.

The **cultivator of killing intent** refines **one qi** to ascend,
the **Three Corpses die of themselves**,
**nine pests are exterminated**,
**Creation’s elixir is forged**,
and **pure yang** becomes the body—
thus it is called the **killing intent**.

When **Heaven and Earth reverse**,
**Creation’s one qi** revives the dead,
thus **yin and yang, Heaven and Earth, reverse**.

When **Heaven and humanity act in unison**,
**ten thousand transformations find their foundation**.

**Heaven and humanity**—
this is **one qi**.
**Acting in unison**—
this is the **initial stir of ascending yang**.
**Ten thousand transformations**—
this is the **change of all things**.
**Foundation**—
this is when all things move by **qi**,
and it is called **establishing the foundation**.

**Nature has skill and clumsiness**,
and can be **concealed and hidden**.
**Law and nature are fundamentally one**,
yet **root natures differ**.
Take **licorice as sweet**,
**yellow gentian as bitter**—
though both stem from **one qi and one root**,
their natures differ.
Humans have **natures of skill and clumsiness**,
which can be **hidden and concealed**.

The *Classic of Changes* says:
*The ruler, if not secretive, loses his ministers;
the minister, if not secretive, loses his life;
secrets of affairs, if not kept hidden, bring ruin.*
From this, it is said:
The **Dao** originates from the **Five Phases**,
so one must know the **nature and disposition** of the Five Phases,
each acting according to its **Phase**,
all relying on **concealment and concealment**.

The *Lüzi* says:
*When the mountain ape sees cunning, it will surely invite calamity.*

「The mountain ape, a kind of monkey, excels at dodging arrows. When the King of Chu went hunting, the mountain ape circled around a tree, and the king, seeing its skill, commanded Yang Youji to shoot it. Youji aimed his arrow, but the mountain ape clung to the tree and cried, knowing Youji was a master archer and that it could not escape—it would surely die. Thus it is said: *Skill invites misfortune*; even if a man is supremely skilled, he cannot escape death unless it is by **Dao/Way’s** design. The **Nine Orifices**’s malice lies in the **Three Senses**, which govern movement and stillness.

The **Nine Orifices** reside in the heart, which contains seven orifices: three fine openings hidden within, and two that conceal **yin and yang**’s essence, one orifice as **yin**, one as **yang**, serving as aids. The **Sovereign**—if he is the heart’s king—thus commands the heart’s nine openings. The **Three Senses**—ears, eyes, and mouth—can perceive **evil colors**, hear **evil sounds**, and taste **evil flavors**. The heart’s nine orifices receive these sensory delights, and so **malicious qi** enters, stirring movement? It lies in the **Three Senses**: if the eyes do not gaze upon **evil colors**, the ears do not listen to **evil sounds**, and the mouth does not indulge **evil flavors**, then the heart’s orifices refuse **malicious qi**, and stillness is achieved.

**Laozi** said:
*Clarify the heart, and the spirit will naturally be pure;
the six desires will cease to arise,
and the three poisons will be annihilated.*

Humans are divided into **seventy-five grades**—the top **twenty-five grades**, the middle **twenty-five grades**, and the lowest **twenty-five grades**. These are further classified into **nine ranks**: the highest rank of the top grades has a heart with nine orifices; the highest rank of the middle grades has a heart with seven orifices; the highest rank of the lower grades has a heart with five openings. The lowest rank of the lowest grades has no orifices at all in the heart; such a person is called **foolish**, no different from a brute beast. The teachings of the **Three Senses** are meant to guard the heart, for they are the gateway to **movement and stillness, life and death**.

**Fire arises from wood**—when misfortune strikes, it will surely prevail.
When **fire arises from wood**, it is the **Dao/Way’s** inverse course;
when **wood generates fire**, it is the **earthly nature’s** proper flow.
Misfortune strikes and prevails because the **earthly nature’s** proper flow is at work: wood is punished and burns itself;
the **Dao/Way’s** inverse course means wood thrives and flourishes.

The **Dao/Way of the human body** follows the **earthly nature’s** proper course—when aligned, it leads to death;
when opposing the **Dao/Way’s** inverse course, it brings life.
The **foolish man** takes his body as wood and lets his heart’s fire rage unchecked—his ignorance and lack of awareness corrupt his body, and when misfortune strikes, it prevails. This is the **foolish man**.

The **Sage**, however, treats his body as wood and his heart as fire—he extinguishes its source, refines and cultivates his body, and through **dark transformation** of form and essence, becomes a **Sage**.

**Deceit arises in the realm**—when the time moves, it will surely collapse.
**Lustful and malicious qi** disturb the heart, dispersing **spirit and qi**.
When the time moves, it will collapse: **spirit and qi** depart from the body, and the heart scatters in ruin.
*The Laozi* says:
*Take the body as the realm,
take **essence-qi** as the people—
when the people scatter, the realm will fall.*
He who knows this and practices **refinement** is called a **Sage**.

**Heaven gives life, Heaven takes life**—this is the **Dao/Way’s** principle.
If one encounters a **Sage** and receives the **oral precepts**,
knows the methods of **refinement**,
and applies them at **child and wu times**,
diligently practicing to transmute the **common mortal’s** coarse bones and turbid **embryonic essence**,
one may attain **limitless longevity**—
such a one is called a **Sage**.

*End of the Yellow Emperor’s* **Obscure Correspondences Classic** *Commentary, Volume One. Begin of Volume Two.*

「The Daoist Master from Jinling, Tang Chun’s commentary on the *Rich Realm and Peaceful People* chapter of the *Laozi*’s teachings:

*The Laozi* says:
*"Take the body as the realm,*
*take essence-qi as the people,*
*and all spirits as the myriad households."*

Tang Chun explains:
*"Essence nourishes the form,*
*qi nourishes the spirit—*
*essence, qi, and spirit are the means to cultivate vigor.*
*Mastering essence to refine the form is called* **Rich Realm**,
*preserving spirit and safeguarding qi is called* **Peaceful People**;
*The Sage’s outward analogy of the family and state*
*is merely a metaphor—*
*within one’s own body,*
*refining essence-qi to cultivate the Great Dao/Way.*

The **Lao Mother** teaches:
*"Sweet wine and delicacies*
*are the axes and spears that destroy one’s nature;*
*lewd sounds and beautiful colors*
*are the chisels and saws that shatter one’s bones.*
*One unknowingly ruins one’s body,*
*thus the people scatter and the realm collapses."*

**Rich Realm and Peaceful People** refers to
*the practice of teaching the methods of refinement.*
*Chapter* here means *illumination.*

**Heaven and Earth, the thieves of all things;**
**All things, the thieves of humanity;**
**Humanity, the thieves of all things.**

*Heaven and Earth are thieves of all things*
*because all things steal Heaven and Earth’s qi to sustain their forms.*
*All things are thieves of humanity*
*because humanity steals from all things to nourish its life and vitality,*
*thus establishing the body and sustaining the form.*
*Humanity is the thief of all things*
*because it fails to discern the nature and inclinations of all things,*
*only to be repaid by all things stealing from humanity in return.*

*For all things’ nature and inclinations*
*are the methods of refining grains.*
*What one consumes should not be overindulged.*
*Refining grains’ method:*
*Five days of abstinence,*
*then internally directing the fire to refine the grains,*
*as if plucking at the nine orifices—*
*eyes like honeycombs,*
*employing the method of smooth refining to purge waste through the bowels,*
*the great sun like white plaster solidifying.*

*The method for urination:*
*After forty-nine days, one may expel cinnabar through the urine.*
*Thus it is said:*
*"Heaven and Earth are stolen by all things,*
*all things are stolen by humanity,*
*and humanity is stolen by all things.*
*With these three thefts,*
*one cannot escape the cycle."*

*If humanity can seize all things’ essence-qi,*
*refine and transform it through grain cultivation,*
*making the intestines and stomach as supple as butter,*
*and harness the original qi to break free from grains,*
*then one escapes all things—*
*but this is not the way of absolute fasting.*

The **Lao Mother** teaches:
*"Heaven and Earth steal from all things,*
*stealing their vitality so that they cannot always flourish*
*but must decline and decay;*
*all things steal from humanity,*
*so that humanity cannot always remain youthful*
*but must age and die;*
*humanity steals from all things,*
*so that humanity cannot always endure.*

*With these three thefts,*
*none realize the mutual stealing of essence-qi,*
*only that their forms are taken.*
*If one neglects this daily,*
*hunger, cold, illness, and disease will arise.*

*But if one practices diligently,*
*the Great Harmony overflows,*
*fragrant vitality thrives,*
*all hundred channels are nourished,*
*and the three passages flow smoothly.*

*Thus, if one fails to properly counter the thieves,*
*one will be repaid by all things’ theft.*
*If one can instead master the theft of form,*
*plunder essence,*
*refine qi,*
*and preserve limitless life,*
*then the three thefts are balanced,*
*and the Three Talents are at peace.*

*Heaven and Earth steal from all things,*
*all things steal from humanity,*
*and humanity steals from all things—*
*all must be in harmony,*
*without excess.*

*If one loses this Dao/Way,*
*one must first be cut down.*
*Thus it is said:*
*"Eat according to the times,*
*and the hundred limbs will be in order;*
*stir the mechanism,*
*and all transformations will be at peace."*

*"Eat according to the times, and the hundred limbs will be in order"*
*means that drinking and eating in accordance with the times*
*allows the hundred channels to settle naturally;*
*but if one eats out of season,*
*the five viscera will not harmonize,*
*the spirit will suffer,*
*and the hundred limbs will be disordered.*

*"Stir the mechanism, and all transformations will be at peace"*
*refers to the movement of Heaven’s mechanism.*

The **Master Lü** says:
*"Heaven’s mechanism is profound and distant—*
*to begin refining it is still too slow.*
*Heaven’s mechanism is*
*the region one inch and three fen below the navel,*
*where the Sage first cultivates*
*the embryo of immortality."*

Yang’s commentary on the *Difficult Classic* states:
*"The movement of qi between the navel and kidneys*
*is the* **elixir field** (*dantian*),
*the root of life and vitality.*
*Cultivators contemplate the spirit,*
*Buddhist monks sit in meditation—*
*all gather true qi below the navel,*
*and this is why."*

*The elixir field contains a divine tortoise;*
*when inhaling and exhaling true qi,*
*it is not done through the mouth and nose.*
*The mouth and nose are*
*the gateways for qi’s entry and exit,*
*while the elixir field is*
*the source of qi,*
*where the Sage begins cultivation,*
*the dwelling place of the True One.*

*Thus it is said:*
*"Fetal breathing is* **qi** (*qì*) *itself."*

*"Stir the mechanism"*
*refers to the* **heart-mind** (*xīn*).

The **Master Shi** says:
*"The heart-mind governs* **qi**,
*and the spirit cultivates the embryo,*
*thus all transformations are at peace."*

The **Lao Mother** teaches:
*"Eating is not about gluttony,*
*but about stealing all things’ essence-qi.*
*Indeed, the form can consume flavors,*
*and the spirit can consume qi.*
*If one eats at the proper times,*
*the form will move,*
*and the mechanism will refine essence,*
*then all transformations will be at peace."*

*Humanity knows its spirit*
*but not the means by which it is spirit.*
*Humanity knows the spirits of yin and yang*
*in fortune and misfortune,*
*but not the spirits of entry and exit within one’s own body,*
*which determine life and death.*

*Humanity knows the spirits of*
*raising and lowering the hands and feet,*
*but not the supreme spirit of Heaven’s mechanism,*
*which moves and directs all things—*
*thus it is called* **spirit within spirit**.

*Humanity knows the qi entering and exiting through*
*the mouth and nose,*
*but not the True One’s qi within the elixir field—*
*thus it is called* **qi within qi**.

*Humanity knows the essence of the five grains,*
*but not the True One’s original essence—*
*thus it is called* **essence within essence**.

The **Lao Master** says:
*"Within essence is essence,*
*within qi is qi,*
*within spirit is spirit—*
*this is my Dao/Way of Nature."*

The **Lao Mother** teaches:
*"Humanity knows the spirits of sacrifices,*
*but not the thirty-six thousand pathways of essence, light, and spirit*
*within one’s own body,*
*which can become the spirits of transcendence.*

*The sun and moon have their cycles,*
*the great and small have their fixed measures.*
*From the Sage’s accomplishments,*
*spirit and brilliance emerge.*

*The numbers of Heaven and Earth are fifty-five,*
*The Great Unfolding’s numbers are fifty,*
*and its applications are forty-nine.*
*The numbers of the Five Phases are:*
*water one,*
*fire two,*
*wood three,*
*metal four,*
*earth five—*
*these are the numbers of life.»

Within essence, there are also **completion numbers**: water six, fire seven, wood eight, metal nine, and earth ten.

Numbers refer to the **thirty radiations** of the *One Qi* (三十辐也).
The **thirty radiations** of the *One Qi* are:
water one, fire two, wood three, metal four,
and the combined total of metal, wood, water, and fire is ten.
Earth has no fixed form—
it thrives according to the seasons,
and in each of the four directions, it holds five numbers.
Four fives make twenty,
then add the ten numbers,
totaling thirty radiations—
this is the use of one month.

Thus, in its movement,
Heaven and Earth generate the numbers of humanity’s *qi*,
and this is the monthly application of numbers.

The **solar numbers** are the *nine-nine* numbers,
whereby one begins counting from the winter solstice,
adding one each day until reaching eighty-one days—
this is the number of the **Great Sun** (太阳).
Five days make one **watch** (侯),
fifteen days make one *qi* (气),
forty-five days make one **node** (节),
and ninety days make one season.
The moon has waxing and waning,
and all things have their fixed allotments—
thus, all calendars, great and small, have their allotted measures,
and from the Sage’s accomplishments,
spirit and brilliance emerge.

Those who cultivate the Dao,
if they follow the numbers of the sun and moon,
extracting and supplementing as needed,
and apply them with skill—
the path of death grows near,
while the way of life is abandoned.
For those who refine their mortal form into true essence,
both spirit and form become wondrous—
would they not become **Immortal Adepts**?

As for **stealing the Mysteries** (盗机),
none under Heaven can see or know it.
Heaven and Earth, all things,
sequentially **steal** from one another—
none can see it,
for they **steal the Mysteries of Heaven and Earth**.

None under Heaven can see it,
because it is **colorless** (无色),
silent to the ear (无声),
formless to the touch (无形),
and nameless when called (无名).
Thus, none under Heaven can see or know it.
They exhaust the **creation of the *One Qi*** (一炁之造化),
and observe the **emergence of all things** (万物之发生)—
thus, none can know it.

The *Book of Transformation* (《化书》) states:
*"Gazing upward at the vast expanse, one sees no trace,*
*dwelling in the void, one hears no sound.*
*Yet spirit and brilliance are not distant—*
*the virtuous person steadies their heart."*

**Yanzi** says:
*"Gazing upward, it grows ever higher,*
*delving deeper, it grows ever firmer,*
*looking forward, it is there,*
*yet suddenly, it is behind.*
*Its clarity is indistinct and formless—*
*how can it be grasped in shape?"*

**Zun** says:
*"Indistinct and formless* (恍惚) *are the source of having and not having.*
Thus, the Sage comprehends the **origin of having and not having** (有无之源),
exhausts the **limit of creation** (造化之端)—
cultivate it, and form and shape emerge.
Thus, it is said:
none can know it,
none can see it.

The **virtuous person**, if they attain it, will endure;
the **petty person**, if they attain it, will perish.
Both the virtuous and petty adjust their **nature and fate** (性命).
The **virtuous person**, attaining their **nature and fate**, will endure—
but if their **nature and fate** should suddenly vanish,
they must **awaken to their true nature** (悟其性),
**nourish their life** (养其命),
and thus prolong their years—
then they will achieve **long life**.

The **petty person**, attaining their **nature and fate** but unable to preserve it,
will lose their **life** and **nature**,
indulging in wine and licentiousness,
their wills fierce yet unsteady—
they do not **consolidate their nature and fate**,
thus it is said:
they **lightly abandon their fate**.

The *I Ching* says:
*"The virtuous person aligns with Heaven and Earth in **virtue/power** (德),
with the sun and moon in **brilliance** (明),
with the four seasons in **order** (序),
and with spirits and ghosts in **auspiciousness and inauspiciousness** (吉凶)."*

The **virtuous person** cultivates **yinyang virtue/power** (阴德) externally,
refines **heart and spirit** (心神) internally,
**consolidates endurance and nourishes life** (固穷养命),
to safeguard their **nature and fate**—
this is the **virtuous person**.

As for the **petty person**,
their actions and movements
do not accord with yinyang, sun, and moon,
they disregard **nature and fate**, **royal law** (王法),
and yet boast, *"I am strong!"*
They obscure the **Dao of the spirits** (神道) in darkness,
possess no **true essence** (寸真) within,
and act without **benevolence** (仁) outside.
They harbor **thorns and brambles** (荆棘),
and Heaven and Earth do not tolerate them.
The **Yin Officials** (阴公) **strip their merit** (夺功) and **divert their calculations** (夺算),
though they live long, their **calamity falls upon their descendants**.
Thus, it is said:
the **petty person** acts recklessly—
thus, they **lightly abandon their fate**.

**Chapter on the Martial Arts of the Strong and the Victorious** (强兵战胜演术章下)

To speak of **martial strength and victory** (强兵战胜),
is it not easy for a hundred thousand to defeat ten thousand,
or for ten to overpower one?
The **virtuous person** contemplates it carefully—
it is not the **art of war**.

**Yuan Shuzhen**, the True Person, says:
*"To wield martial strength and achieve victory,
one must enter battle with **heroic vigor** (雄豪).
If **Huang Gong**’s *Three Strategies* (《三略》),
**Lu Wang**’s *Six Canons* (《六韬》),
and **Sunzi**’s *Thirteen Chapters* (《十三篇》)
are applied—
to defeat the many with the few,
the strong with the weak,
and the few with the many—
turning defeat into victory,
this is the **three martial arts** (三兵法).
Is it not the case of many against few?"*

**Zun** says:
The Sage likens cultivation to the **art of war**,
to **pacify chaos** (治乱).
The **direct pointing at the *One Heart*** (直指一心) likens **contending for victory** (争胜).
If the **heart** remains undisturbed,
a hundred evils find no entry.
If **nature** is turbid,
*qi* becomes disordered,
and the **path of life** grows distant.

If the **heart** is tranquil,
the **Dao** arises,
and **Immortal Adepts** come naturally.

**Li Chong** says:
**Martial strength** (强兵) is the **Great Dao of Heavenly Mastery** (大道天师),
the **Sovereign of All Transformations** (万化之主),
the **descending sword-qi of demons** (降魔剑气).
If one attains this Dao,
**greed, wrath, delusion, and poison** (贪嗔痴毒),
the **six thieves** (六贼) without **enlightenment** (无明),
**spirits and ghosts** (神鬼) without **auspiciousness** (不祥),
and **demonic illusions and Yin Demons** (妖伪阴魔) all collapse in unison—
only the **Supreme Venerable** (至尊) remains visible.

This is the **mysterious Dao of the Ancient Sage** (太古玄道),
called **martial strength**.

The **Ancient Sage’s intent** (古圣之立法) was to **subdue demons and pacify chaos** (降魔治乱),
to **teach and transform** (教化) the world in **tranquility** (清静).
How could it be the **Dao of sharp weapons and martial strength** (锐武强兵),
of **chaotic campaigns and the slaughter of life** (乱役生灵),
of **killing and harming nature and fate** (杀害性命),
of **inviting retribution and accumulating karmic debts** (招冤引业),
and of **bringing calamity upon descendants** (祸累子孙)?
The chapter speaks of **Sun Wu and Han Bai** (孙吴韩白),
all of whom mastered the **art of martial strength and victory** (强兵战胜之术).
As for the **laws of attack and warfare** (攻战之法),
**martial strength and Yin stratagems** (兵强阴谋) are deceitful—
they **sacrifice life to extinguish life** (以命煞命),
and the **actions of spirits and ghosts** (神鬼之行)
do not truly grasp the **intent of the *Yinfu*** (《阴符》).

The **Ancient Sage’s true intent** (古圣人旨趣) is this:
**Nourishing and consolidating** (摄养) are the **martial arts of strength and victory**.

The **blind excel in hearing**,
the **deaf excel in sight**—
**severing the single source of profit** (绝利一源),
they **employ tenfold the troops** (用师十倍);
**threefold reversals of day and night** (三反昼夜),
they **employ ten-thousandfold the troops** (用师万倍).
The **blind excel in hearing**,
the **deaf excel in sight**—
**Zun** says:
*"They are fixated on **sounds and colors** (声色)."*
If **sounds and colors** are forgotten,
the **single source of profit** is severed—
cultivation is enhanced tenfold,
and **consolidating and nourishing** (运养) to preserve **true nature** (固性)
allows one to **attain singular focus**.

As for **spirit and brilliance** (精神) employing troops,
they are the **martial arts**.

Again, **troops** are **martial arts**,
they are the **many**—
thus, this reasoning is **logically flawed** (文理可否),
and the **words do not align with the Dao** (言不合道)."

Li Chong said:
**"Troops" is not a term for martial arts.** The Great Dao is true, one, and supreme. The most august Emperor Yuan Shi, the sovereign of all beings, taught the Dao through scriptures and names—turning away from external forms and focusing inward—thus employing tenfold the troops. **Threefold reversals** occur in day and night, employing ten-thousandfold the troops.

Zhun said: **"Threefold reversals"** refer to *shen-qi-jing* (spirit-qi-essence). When *shen* returns to *qi*, the heart commands the spirit, and the spirit commands the heart. When *qi* returns to *jing*, it is the essence-fire; fire descends below, and water ascends to surge. Having reached *ji* (completion), the reverse occurs—when applied, it surpasses limits.

The **Tail Gate** (尾闾) connects the brain’s posterior, the spinal column, and the kidney meridian, ascending through *jiā jǐ* (夹脊), *shuāng guān* (双关), *fēng fǔ* (风府), *ní wán* (泥丸), and the *bǎi huì* (百会) acupoint, then flowing through the *míng táng* (明堂), *dòng fáng* (洞房), and nasal ridge, entering the *dān tiān* (丹田). It then returns through the **Divine Perilous Gate** (神巍), flowing endlessly—blood transforming into marrow. This is where the **immortal’s method** directs *jing-qi* into the *ní wán*—thus employing ten-thousandfold the troops.

The **Adrift-and-Soaring Master** said:
*"Each full cycle lifted, paired with the immortals as companions."*

The **Bright Master** said:
*"If one masters the nine *ní* (泥) orifices, why bother refining the Great Elixir?"*

It is further said:
*"From *jiā jǐ* (夹脊) and *shuāng guān* (双关) to the crown, this is the path of cultivation’s root."*

The *Sutra of Upper Birth* states:
*"Its water surging upward, drifting between the beams and rafters—this is it."*

The heart arises from things and perishes in them; its mechanism lies in the eyes.
**The mechanism lies in the eyes**—Yuan Shu’s True Person said:
*"The heart is the source of desire; the eyes are the root of color. The eyes govern seeing; the heart governs knowing. If the heart does not know, the eyes cannot discern—thus the saying."*

Zhun said:
*"When the eyes see one thing, without cause they move.
When the heart fixates on one thing, it follows without restraint.
The true heart does not wither; the vital organism falls ill.
Dispersing the true essence—this is not perishing in things."*

**The mechanism lies in the eyes**—if the eyes are flawed, black and white are indistinct, and the divine light is dimmed, such a person has death but no life. **To perish in things** is to be one who attains the Dao. If the eyes govern seeing while the heart remains unmoved, and *shen-qi* circulates without *jing* leaking, such a person has life but no death. **The mechanism lies in the eyes**—if black and white are clearly distinguished, the essence is untainted, and the divine light shines naturally—this is the mechanism of the eyes.

The ancients said:
*"Living mercury nourishes the dead; dead mercury nourishes the living."*
**Mercury** in humans governs the essence.

The *Medical Texts* state:
*"The heart weighs twelve *liǎng*; its stored essence is three *hé*."*

Thus, the vital organism resides in the heart. If the essence dies and mercury dries, the scriptures say *perishing in things*. Hence:
*"Dead mercury nourishes the living*—this is the True Person;
*Living mercury nourishes the dead*—the cultivator’s essence and *qi* cannot congeal, and mercury cannot dry—this is the dead."*

Thus, living mercury means the person dies.

All who refine for immortality are human. Heaven, though without favor, gives birth to great benevolence. Heaven does not originally bestow grace, yet at the appointed time, it moves—true *qi* ascends and surges, and all things arise. All things receive Heaven’s great grace and endure.

Swift thunder and fierce winds move all things sluggishly. Yin and yang release, and Heaven and Earth’s *qi* exchange; the utmost essence acts naturally, producing sound, and all things move sluggishly to life.

Human cultivation is no different: at the *zi-wu* hours, yin and yang coalesce to form essence. *Kàn-lǐ* (坎离) *qi* exchanges; water and fire are completed—naturally producing sound, like swift thunder and fierce winds. The utmost essence releases and makes its sound; yin dissipates, yang purifies, and one soars through the cloudy heavens—is this not immortality?

All taking and using align with yin and yang; all are the work of the utmost essence.

The **Venerable Mother** said:
*"When humans refine yin-yang *qi* in a misty haze, like wind in motion, like thunder’s voice, they flow harmoniously, purifying and removing impurities, generating fluids for the five viscera, and harmonizing the hundred bones. Thus, the Dao of True One is preserved."*

**Supreme joy leaves no residue**; supreme stillness is **uprightness**.
**Supreme joy leaves no residue**—this is joy in Heaven’s Dao.
Stillness is returning to the root.
Thus, it is said: *"Stillness is uprightness—the Dao."*
Joy is Heaven’s nature, extending to life.
The **Venerable Mother** said:
*"Seeking nothing externally, doubting nothing internally—this is the Dao of supreme joy."*
Supreme joy is the utmost joy; innate nature leaves no residue. Common nature attains true stillness—this is having residue.

Common people take delight in the joy of descendants and entertainment—this is not the sage’s joy.

Neither mountains are inherently still, nor markets inherently noisy. The sage, awakening to nature, takes nourishing life as stillness; attaining the One is uprightness.

*The Book of Kang Cang* says:
*"Nobility brings verbal harmony; wealth brings bodily harmony; poverty brings mental harmony; stillness brings spiritual harmony—these are the four harmonies."*

Heaven’s utmost privacy is used with utmost publicness.
Heaven’s subtle formation of all things hides mechanisms within.
Thus, it is said: *"Utmost privacy used with utmost publicness"*—generating all classes, each attaining its Dao—this is called utmost fairness, using fairness to govern all things.

**The nature of birds lies in *qi*.**
The sage likens soaring birds to feathered immortals—birds ride the *qi* to ascend to the azure heavens; humans cannot match this.

Though humans are the most intelligent of all things, they cannot subdue the *qi* of virtue and morality. Thus, they cultivate in poverty to nourish life. If one skillfully uses the *qi* of virtue and morality, like a dragon shedding its bones, a serpent sloughing its skin, or a cicada casting its shell, humans refine and transform, entering the Great Luo, ascending to the celestial river—is this not difficult?

Even at the ninth heaven above, all are those who have entered sainthood from the mundane.

*The Sacred Words of the Jade Emperor* say:
*"Thus, the high officials of the nine heavens, the True Lords of Destiny, embrace pure essence and obtain the *hun yuan* (混元) *qi*—only then can they transcend the mundane and enter sainthood."*

The cultivator, if refining the *hun yuan* *qi* into pure essence, fully becoming an extreme-yang body, becomes an immortal—how could this be difficult?

The mundane and the learned alike—if they do not see what they study—are like standing beyond a mountain of ten thousand *li*, great or small, the same.

The **Dao/Way** of the sages lies in subduing the source of **virtue/power** and seizing the creative function of Heaven and Earth.

Suppose water reaches the winter cold and congeals into ice—this is not the extreme of cold, but it meets the **shuò fēng** (朔风) and then congeals.
**Shuò fēng** (朔风) is the **north wind**.

In the summer months, it does not fear the heat, but fears the **south wind** that can dissolve its ice, later returning it to water.
Thus, the true essence of humanity, when congealed into **elixir**, relies on the **north wind**—the **qi** of the kidneys.

When the essence congeals into **elixir**, it must transform into the **true unity** (真一) essence.
The **south wind**—the **heart fire**—converts essence into **qi**, suffusing the Four Great Elements (四大), with pure yang flowing forth, and humanity knows no death or life.

**Lǎo Mǔ** (老母) says:
*"Even winged creatures that traverse the void of Dao/Way rely on their **qi**—how much more so for humans, the most refined of all beings! Those who cultivate and refine themselves can become entirely pure yang in form, their **qi** then able to penetrate metals and stones without obstruction, to move with the sun and moon without trace—how could they not transform their form and attain **fruit** (证果), ride the **qi** and wander the **mystic** (玄)?"*

Life is the root of death;
Death is the root of life.

The heart clings to fame and profit, lavishly nourishing one’s family;
It indulges in lust and desire for color, hoarding wealth and goods—
Others see this as the **Dao/Way of life**,
I see it as the root of death.

Death is also the root of life.
If one does not covet what is not profit,
Knowing one’s proper measure and what is fitting,
Honors and decay await one’s destiny,
Guarding the mind with single resolve,
Ever holding to the conduct of the **gentleman** (君子),
Skilled in peril and salvation,
Not harming the life of any being,
Mastering oneself and dwelling in **ren** (仁),
Accumulating essence and preserving spirit—
Then death is the root of life.

Life is the root of death.
When the root of death dies, life arises;
Life and death depend on the root.
The **root** is the heart and the kidneys.
The heart’s life is death,
The heart’s death is life.
The heart is the root of the **spirit** (神),
The kidneys are the root of the **qi**—
The heart’s death brings stillness to nature,
The kidneys’ death preserves the vital breath;
The heart’s activity breeds nature’s greed,
The kidneys’ activity causes essence to leak.
Thus, the key lies in firmly guarding the root—
Only then can one attain **long life** and **enduring vision**.

**Virtue/power** arises from harm,
Harm arises from **virtue/power**.

Heaven and Earth, through the **yin** and **yang** **qi**, give **virtue/power** and harm to all beings,
Yet all beings, in their emotions and nature, **steal** (反盗) Heaven and Earth’s **qi**—
Hence it is said: **virtue/power** arises from harm.

Heaven bestows both **virtue/power** and harm—
Autumn’s killing and spring’s birthing—
Hence it is said: harm arises from **virtue/power**.

Great and small alike, no distinction between inner and outer.
The **Dao/Way** is the origin of both **virtue/power** and harm.
Cultivate it, and life will be prolonged;
Neglect it, and life will be shortened.

The foolish see Heaven and Earth’s patterns as superior—
I see the patterns of time and things as profound.

The foolish see Heaven and Earth’s patterns as superior—
All observe the stars and constellations,
Using their patterns to discern auspiciousness and inauspiciousness,
Calamity and fortune, survival and loss—
Hence they are called patterns.

The sages know nothing of their own life and death—
These are the foolish.

I see the patterns of time and things as profound—
For I observe a single thing and know its flourishing and decline,
See a single thing and grasp its life and death,
All in the power of discernment.
My life is in my own hands—
I reverse my gaze upon a single thing and perceive the Great **Dao/Way**,
Examine a single thing and discern auspiciousness and inauspiciousness—
Thus life and death are in my grasp.
My life is in my own hands—
I return to youth from age,
Arise from death to life—
Hence I see the patterns of time and things as profound."

**Chún** (淳) says:
*"I have briefly expounded this **sutra** (经) through its minor details,
Yet I do not establish rigid chapters or phrases—
I merely clarify its meaning and illuminate its words."*

The **Yellow Emperor’s** *Obscure **Yin** **Sutra*** (阴符经) concludes here.

**Title:** *Commentary on the Yellow Emperor’s* **Yin Fu Jing** *(Obscure Classic)*

**Author:** *Commentary on the Yellow Emperor’s* **Yin Fu Jing** *by Tang Chun (唐淳), compiled in the* **Jingyi (己丑)** *year of the reign* **Zhengda (正大)** *of Emperor Aizong of Jin (金哀宗). Two volumes. Source text:* **Zhengtong Daozang (正统道藏)***, Treasure of the Cavern of Perfection (洞真部), Jade Precepts (玉诀类).*

---

**Preface to the Commentary on the Yellow Emperor’s* **Yin Fu Jing** *

Only those who penetrate the profound mysteries of the heavens can elucidate the subtleties of the **Dao/Way**. How could one who has not yet attained the realm of the sages interpret the sages’ scriptures?

Why so? The sages’ words are vast as the heavens—how could those who do not delve into enigmas and unravel hidden meanings ever grasp them?

Take, for instance, the Yellow Emperor’s *Yin Fu Jing*—its chapters are but one or two, its text scarcely three hundred words. Though concise in expression, its meaning is profound and distant; though simple in form, its intent is boundless and intricate.

Some may take it as a method for enriching the state and securing the people, others as a strategy for strengthening armies and achieving victory. It encompasses all of heaven and earth, synthesizes the principles of **yin and yang**, yet appears without form or sound—so subtle that one can intuitively perceive its essence, yet so elusive that its depths cannot be fully plumbed.

Unless one’s inner and outer self is clear and unobstructed, one’s surface and depths polished and refined, unless one can grasp the **Dao/Way** of heaven and earth and command the interplay of **yin and yang**, who could first dissect and then annotate it?

Yet many have commented on this text, but only Master Tang has truly captured the sages’ subtle intent.

Master Tang’s given name was **Chun (淳)**, and he styled himself the **Jinling Daoist (金陵道人)**. His origins remain unknown.

Thus, he expounded what he had heard, aligned with the sages’ intent, and supplemented with references from other works to verify it. For those who come after, when they read the original text, they may find its profundity and remoteness daunting—but when they consult his commentary, they will discover its clarity and accessibility.

Each word he elucidates is like a lamp dispelling darkness; each phrase he interprets is like a tortoise shell divining doubt.

Had Master Tang not inherently known the source of all existence, had he not deeply explored the origins of **creation/transformation (造化)**, had he not penetrated the **Dao/Way’s** mysteries and entered the sages’ realm, how could he have achieved this?

In recent times, **Yingran Zi (莹然子)**—a disciple of **Zhou Zhiming (周至明)**—has emerged, a scholar of our age. Inspired by the Yellow Emperor’s legends while visiting the **Kongtong Mountains (崆峒)**, he was moved by a desire to preserve and refine the **Dao/Way**, and thus sought this annotated text to engrave and print it.

May practitioners of the **Dao/Way** thereby discern the true from the false, attain sainthood while remaining in the mortal realm, hold **yin and yang** in their palms, and encompass the sun and moon within their chests—truly embodying the sages’ original purpose.

He requested I write a preface, and though I wished to decline, I feared the sin of not praising a worthy friend.

Thus, I took up my brush and composed this, merely to honor Master Tang’s noble endeavor.

Written in the **Jingyi (己丑)** year of **Zhengda (正大)**, at **Huoze (濩泽)**, by **Meng Shao (孟绰)**.

chunks.original_text: 神仙抱一演道章 夫神者，在目为视，在耳为听，在舌为言，在鼻则闻香，在手则拳握，在足则行； 昼则为想，夜则为梦； 呼则来，遣则去； 在心为志，言为文章。 无质之间，聚散无迹。 入则为情状，出则为虚无； 散则宇宙九夷无所不至，隐然则微尘芥子无所不入。 存乎丹田，出世为神仙。 若昏昧为下鬼而有余神，散者意，聚者气，气行则神行，气聚则神聚。 《易》曰：阴阳不测之谓神。 又曰：神在丹田，气结为胎。 真气不散，神明自来。 故神炁相守，岂不为长生之道？ 神是炁之子，炁是神之母。 《道经》曰：既知其子，复守其母。 淳曰：子母相守，神仙之道。 施真人曰：神炁若不散，保为长生人也。 仙者，迁也。 凡人为神仙，仙字，人傍着山。 凡人修炼，性如山岳，神气不动不摇，故人傍着山也。 夫神仙二字，得道之人称也。 喻人称郎字者，为有财宝见之称也。 抱者，包藏之意也。 一者，道也。 故言抱一者演道章上是也。 观天之道，执天之行，尽矣。 观者，观也。 上音官字，下音贯字。 仰者观，俯者观。 观者，六门之观想也。 释氏云：摄景归心谓之观想。 故谓之六门之锁闭，内不出，外不入，名观行法。 仰者，观也。 观者，见也。 观见天道，北斗直下，太一真君炁也，名曰太一。 阴真君曰：太一含真炁是也。 凡书云：畜之为元精，施之为万灵，含之为太一，放之为太清。 太一直下，真一运行； 太一直上，北斗直符。 斗者为柄，但观北斗月建，以天道观正月建，寅道在寅是也。 周而复始，运行不绝。 一气升降，日月流行； 五星六曜，森罗万象，无不运行。 故曰：五日一侯，十五日一气，四十五日一节，九十日一季。 春生夏长，秋收冬藏； 发生万物，天上天下，仙宫人世，胎卵湿化，一根一苗，一枝一叶，一花一子，有情无情，皆受道炁而所产也。 故万物内外莫不是道也。 故见天道运行，又观人道不别於天道也。 人道太一两肾，堂间中黄，上赤下黑，左青右白，其包五行、混元一、点真一之道，名曰太一。 太一者，水之宗号。 北斗直符者，心之七窍也。 日月者，心肾也。 人无日月，以心肾为日月； 天无心肾，以日月为心肾。 五星六曜，五脏六腑。 森罗万象者，是皮毛骨节三万六千精光神也。 《道经》云：不出户，知天下也。 河上公曰：人身喻似天地之用也。 又将自己太一运行，日月循环，直得真。 心火下降，肾水上腾，水上火下，五脏百脉生津。 气津液血神自然通流，五行四象八卦万神自归大道。 百骸九窍自得通灵，手握太一，性命固穷。 若是依天道运行，岂不与天地齐寿矣？ 故曰：执天之行，尽矣。 是故圣人指天道喻人观天道之运行。 执天之行，无不成神仙者矣。 天有五贼，见之者昌。 得贼则昌，失则亡。 七贤云：五星、五岳、五脏、五方、五贼，五贼五行之义，洪儒珍重之言，无不包也。 淳曰：天地用五行，递相为克伐，相生相投也。 天之五贼，木、水、金、土、火； 地之五贼，金、木、水、火、土。 见圣人言天之五贼逆行，阴阳颠倒相返也，地之五贼随地顺行，故人有生死矣。 若见天贼，随天贼而运用，故人只有生而无死也。 故曰：见之者昌矣。 且见地之五行，金生水之类也，天之五行，则不然也，即水生金也。

「The *Bao Yi* Chapter on the Dao/Way of the Immortals and Divine Ones
The divine, when in the eyes, is vision;
when in the ears, is hearing;
when in the tongue, is speech;
when in the nose, perceives fragrance;
when in the hands, manifests as clenched fists;
when in the feet, becomes movement.

By day, it takes form as thought;
by night, as dreams.
When summoned, it comes;
when dismissed, it departs.
In the mind, it is will;
in speech, it is eloquence.

Between formlessness, it gathers and scatters without trace.
Within, it becomes emotional states;
without, it dissolves into emptiness.
When scattered, it permeates the cosmos and the Nine Barbarians—nowhere is untouched.
When concealed, it enters even minute dust particles and sesame seeds.

It resides in the **elixir field (Dan Tian)**, and when cultivated, one becomes an immortal.

If one is dull and confused, the excess becomes a lower ghost.
Scattered, it is the mind;
gathered, it is the **qi**.
When **qi** moves, the divine moves;
when **qi** gathers, the divine gathers.

The *Yijing (I Ching)* says: *"The unfathomable interplay of yin and yang is called the divine."*

It further states: *"The divine dwells in the elixir field; the **qi** condenses into an embryo."*
True **qi** does not disperse,
the divine and luminous naturally arise.
Thus, the divine and **qi** mutually uphold one another—
is this not the Dao/Way of longevity?

The divine is the child of **qi**,
**qi** is the mother of the divine.
The *Dao De Jing (Laozi’s Classic of the Dao)* says: *"Knowing its child, yet preserving its mother."*

Tang Chun says: *"The mutual preservation of child and mother is the Dao/Way of the immortals."*

Master Shi Zhenren says: *"If divine and **qi** do not disperse,
one is naturally a longevity cultivator."*

The term *immortal (xian)* means *transcendence*.
Common folk call those who attain the Dao/Way *immortals*,
where the character *xian* (仙) is *ren* (人) beside *shan* (山, mountain).
When common folk refine themselves,
their nature is like mountains and rivers—
their divine **qi** undisturbed and unshaken,
thus, *ren* beside *shan* also.

The terms *immortals and divine ones (shenxian)* are titles for those who have attained the Dao/Way.
Just as people call others *郎 (lang)*—
a term for those with wealth and status—
*immortals* refers to those who have cultivated the Dao/Way and embraced the treasures within.

*Bao* (抱) means *to embrace and conceal*.
*Yi* (一) signifies the *Dao/Way*.
Thus, the chapter *"Bao Yi"* is indeed the beginning of the exposition on the Dao/Way.

To observe the Dao/Way of Heaven,
and to grasp Heaven’s operations—
that is all.

*Observe (guan)* means *to contemplate*,
with the upper tone as *guan* (官, official) and the lower as *guan* (贯, pierce).
To look upward is to observe;
to look downward is to observe.
*Observe* refers to the contemplation of the Six Gates.

The Buddhist school says: *"To internalize the external forms and return them to the mind is called contemplation (guanxiang)."*
Thus, it is called the *locking of the Six Gates*—
within, nothing escapes;
without, nothing enters—
this is the method of *guanxing*.

To look upward is to observe;
*Observe* means *to perceive*.
To perceive the Dao/Way of Heaven,
the **North Dipper (Bei Dou)** aligns directly below,
the **True One of the Supreme Unity (Tai Yi Zhen Jun)** is the **qi** of Heaven—
its name is **Tai Yi** (太一).

The **Yin True One (Yin Zhen Jun)** says: *"Tai Yi contains the true **qi**."*

Common texts state:
*"To store it is the **original essence (Yuan Jing)**;
to apply it is **vitality (Wan Ling)**;
to contain it is **Tai Yi**;
to release it is **Tai Qing (太清)**."*

When **Tai Yi** descends directly,
the **True One (Zhen Yi)** operates;
when **Tai Yi** ascends directly,
the **North Dipper** aligns with its symbols.

The **Dipper (Dou)** is the handle;
merely observe the **North Dipper’s** monthly stations—
the Dao/Way of Heaven observed in the first month’s station,
the **Tiger (Yin)** in the **Tiger** month—
cycling endlessly without cessation.

One **qi** ascends and descends,
the sun and moon revolve;
the **Five Stars** and **Six Celestial Lights (Liu Yao)**,
arranged in myriad forms—
all operate in harmony.

Thus it is said:
*"Five days mark a **host (hou)**,
fifteen days mark a **qi**,
forty-five days mark a **node (jie)**,
ninety days mark a **season (ji)**."*

Spring generates, summer lengthens,
autumn harvests, winter stores.
It gives rise to all things—
Heaven above, Heaven below,
palaces of the immortals, realm of mortals,
embryos, eggs, damp transformations—
one root, one sprout,
one branch, one leaf,
one blossom, one fruit—
sentient and insentient alike,
all receive the **Dao/Way’s qi** and are thereby produced.

Thus, all things within and without are none other than the Dao/Way itself.
Therefore, when one perceives the Dao/Way of Heaven’s operations,
one also observes that human cultivation does not differ from Heaven’s Dao/Way.

The Dao/Way of humanity:
**Tai Yi** resides between the two kidneys,
with a yellow center in the hall,
red above and black below,
blue-green to the left and white to the right—
its embrace of the Five Phases,
the **Supreme Unity (Hun Yuan Yi)**,
the **True One (Zhen Yi)**,
is called **Tai Yi**.

**Tai Yi** is the sovereign name of **water**.
The **North Dipper’s** alignment is the **seven orifices of the heart (Xin Qi Qiao)**.
The sun and moon are the **heart and kidneys**.
Humans without sun and moon,
use the heart and kidneys as sun and moon;
Heaven without heart and kidneys,
uses the sun and moon as heart and kidneys.

The **Five Stars** and **Six Celestial Lights** correspond to the **Five Zang Organs** and **Six Fu Organs**.
The *"myriad forms"* are the **36,000 divine lights** of skin, hair, bones, and joints.

The *Dao De Jing* says: *"Without leaving one’s door, one knows the affairs of the world."*
Master He Shang Gong says: *"The human body is likened to Heaven and Earth’s operations."*

Moreover, when one aligns their own **Tai Yi** with its celestial movement,
the sun and moon revolve in harmony,
and the true essence is attained.

When the **heart’s fire** descends and the **kidney’s water** ascends,
water above and fire below,
the **Five Zang Organs** and **hundred meridians** produce **vital fluids (jin ye)**.
The **qi**, **vital fluids**, **blood**, and **divine lights** flow naturally,
the **Five Phases**, **Four Symbols**, **Eight Trigrams**, and **myriad divine essences** return to the Great Dao/Way.
The **hundred bones** and **nine orifices** attain **spiritual responsiveness (Tong Ling)**,
the hands grasp **Tai Yi**,
and **life and vitality are secured**.

If one follows the Dao/Way of Heaven’s operations,
will they not live as long as Heaven and Earth?
Thus it is said: *"To grasp Heaven’s operations—
that is all."*

Therefore, the sages point to Heaven’s Dao/Way,
and liken human cultivation to observing Heaven’s operations.
To grasp Heaven’s operations,
there is none who does not become an immortal.

Heaven has **Five Thieves (Wu Ze)**;
those who perceive them flourish.
To obtain the thieves is to flourish;
to lose them is to perish.

The **Seven Worthies (Qi Xian)** say:
*"The Five Stars, Five Mountains, Five Zang Organs, Five Directions, and Five Thieves—
these are the Five Thieves’ alignment with the Five Phases,
a treasure held by the profound scholars,
all-encompassing in meaning."*

Tang Chun says:
*"Heaven and Earth employ the Five Phases,
each alternately restraining and generating the others.
Heaven’s Five Thieves are:
**wood, water, metal, earth, and fire**;
Earth’s Five Thieves are:
**metal, wood, water, fire, and earth**.

The sages say that Heaven’s Five Thieves move in reverse,
yin and yang inverted and returning;
Earth’s Five Thieves follow Earth’s natural order,
thus humans have life and death.

If one perceives Heaven’s thieves,
and operates in accordance with them,
then humans have only life and no death.

Thus it is said: *"Those who perceive them flourish."*

Moreover, when observing Earth’s Five Phases,
**metal** generates **water**—
but Heaven’s Five Phases are otherwise,
for **water** generates **metal** instead.»

The **Four Symbols** and **Two Principles** are further combined with the **Steel-and-Water Earth** (戊己土), hence it is said that the **Five Phases do not proceed in order**, and when the **Four Symbols** merge into the **Central Palace**, it is called the **Method of Inverted Five Phases**.

The **True Master Taibai** said:
*The Method of Inverted Five Phases*—
the **Dragon emerges from fire**.

*The Five Phases do not proceed in order*—
the **Tiger is born in water**.

The **True One Son** said:
These twenty characters—
few in number yet profound in meaning—
are called **revealing the mutual interplay of Heaven and Earth**.

The **Yin True Lord** said:
The **true qi of the North** is called the **River Vehicle**,
while the **East’s Jia-Yi** forms **golden sand**.
The **Vermilion Bird** regulates its movement to generate **golden splendor**,
and **golden splendor** produces the **Heaven-Earth Treasure**.

If one comprehends these words,
harmonizing **inner and outer Dao**,
aligning with the **Heaven-Earth Way**,
and refining essence into **spiritual elixir**,
then **transmuting the Four Great Elements**,
one may ascend lightly—
is this not the **Dao of Immortals and Transcendents**?
Thus it is said:
*Those who perceive this flourish.*

The **Five Bandits** reside in the heart,
and their influence extends to Heaven.
The **Five Bandits** in the heart—
these are the **true qi of the Five Phases**.
With the heart as sovereign,
movement stirs the Five Phases in response.
Thus it is said:
*The Five Bandits reside in the heart.*

When their influence extends to Heaven,
one must align with the **Heavenly Dao**,
for all good and evil originate from the heart.
All actions must conform to Heaven’s **Way**,
and when the heart acts,
it harmonizes with the **Five Bandits of Heaven** in their operations.

The **universe lies within the hand**,
and **ten thousand transformations arise from the body**.
The **universe lies within the hand**,
and **ten thousand transformations arise from the body**—
this is where **Immortal cultivation begins**,
the **craft of sages and worthies**,
the **authority of yin and yang**.

Yin and yang—
these are **Sun and Moon**.
The **Sun is the Dragon**,
the **Moon is the Tiger**;
the **Sun is Mercury**,
the **Moon is Lead**;
the **Sun is Li**,
the **Moon is Kan**;
the **Sun is Fire**,
the **Moon is Water**;
the **Sun is the yang soul**,
the **Moon is the yin spirit**;
the **Sun is qi**,
the **Moon is essence**;
the **Sun is nature**,
the **Moon is fate**.

He who grasps the universe
holds **life and death in his hand**.
My fate lies within me,
not in Heaven—
in Heaven, it is the **Sun and Moon**;
in man, it is **essence and qi**.
Heaven moves by the **Sun and Moon’s revolution**,
while man moves by the **circulation of essence and qi**.

The **True Master Lü** said:
When someone asked me of the **cultivation method**,
I pointed to the **Sun and Moon’s wheel** in the sky.

**Wei Boyang’s** *Parametric Contract* sings:
*The Sage seizes the intent of Creation,*
*supporting Sun and Moon within the furnace.*
*Subtly reversing Heaven-Earth’s essence,*
*drilling through yin and yang to command spirits.*
*If one recognizes the Sun’s soul and Moon’s spirit,*
*the knower is a child of the Immortals.*
*Refine and ingest for a thousand days—*
*when the body lacks no yin, how can death come?*

The *Plain Questions* [□] *On Ancient Celestial Truth* says:
*I have heard that the ancient True Ones upheld Heaven and Earth,*
*grasped yin and yang,*
*inhaled essence-qi,*
*stood alone guarding the spirit,*
*their flesh and muscles unified—*
*thus they could live as long as Heaven and Earth,*
*without beginning or end.*

Zhang Menggan said:
*Containing Heaven and Earth in the palm,*
*gathering and dispersing the Three Celestial Lights;*
*holding Sun and Moon at the chest,*
*rolling and unfolding the Eight Scenes.*

The *Dao De Jing* says:
*Deep roots and firm foundations—*
*the Dao of eternal life and longevity.*

The **Sun and Moon reside in heart and kidney**,
the **heart is prone to movement**,
the **spirit prone to leaking essence**.
Thus the **Sage restrains the heart from moving**,
grasp the **kidney to prevent leakage**—
when firm and unbroken,
the body becomes light,
and thus **eternal life and longevity** are attained.
Is this not the **starting point of Immortal cultivation**,
where **heart and kidney interact**,
**essence and qi reverse**,
and **ten thousand transformations arise from the body**?

Thus it is said:
*The mechanisms of Immortal transformation—*
*to turn ghosts into Immortals,*
*to revive the dead as the living—*
*this is the universe within the hand.*

When **Heaven unleashes the killing intent**,
**dragons and serpents rise from the earth**.

This is the **inner alchemy of the Three Hundred Characters**—
**Heaven’s nature** is **humanity**;
**human heart** is the **mechanism**.
Establishing **Heaven’s Way** to **determine humanity**.
These sixteen characters were added by **Du Guangting**.

Chun said:
When **Heaven unleashes the killing intent**,
it is the **third month of autumn**,
when the **West’s metal-qi** brings frost,
capable of killing all things.
Metal can overcome wood,
so dragons and serpents retreat underground,
and all things may be killed.
The *Dao De Jing* says:
*Heaven and Earth are not kind—they treat all things as sacrificial dogs.*

**Dragons and serpents rising from the earth**—
this is the **third month of spring**,
when all things sprout,
and Heaven-Earth renew.
Autumn kills, spring generates—
this is the **principle of the Way**.
Spring is the **Tai co-ordinate**,
autumn is the **Pi co-ordinate**—
spring generates, autumn kills—
this is the **meaning of Heaven-Earth’s reversal**.

When **humanity unleashes the killing intent**,
**Heaven and Earth reverse**.
The greatest **human killing intent** is **filial disobedience**,
a crime without pardon,
hence **Heaven and Earth reverse**.

The **cultivator of killing intent** refines **one qi** to ascend,
the **Three Corpses die of themselves**,
**nine pests are exterminated**,
**Creation’s elixir is forged**,
and **pure yang** becomes the body—
thus it is called the **killing intent**.

When **Heaven and Earth reverse**,
**Creation’s one qi** revives the dead,
thus **yin and yang, Heaven and Earth, reverse**.

When **Heaven and humanity act in unison**,
**ten thousand transformations find their foundation**.

**Heaven and humanity**—
this is **one qi**.
**Acting in unison**—
this is the **initial stir of ascending yang**.
**Ten thousand transformations**—
this is the **change of all things**.
**Foundation**—
this is when all things move by **qi**,
and it is called **establishing the foundation**.

**Nature has skill and clumsiness**,
and can be **concealed and hidden**.
**Law and nature are fundamentally one**,
yet **root natures differ**.
Take **licorice as sweet**,
**yellow gentian as bitter**—
though both stem from **one qi and one root**,
their natures differ.
Humans have **natures of skill and clumsiness**,
which can be **hidden and concealed**.

The *Classic of Changes* says:
*The ruler, if not secretive, loses his ministers;
the minister, if not secretive, loses his life;
secrets of affairs, if not kept hidden, bring ruin.*
From this, it is said:
The **Dao** originates from the **Five Phases**,
so one must know the **nature and disposition** of the Five Phases,
each acting according to its **Phase**,
all relying on **concealment and concealment**.

The *Lüzi* says:
*When the mountain ape sees cunning, it will surely invite calamity.*

chunks.original_text: 山狙者，猿也，善能避箭。 楚王出猎，山狙绕树，王见巧，令养由基射猿。 由基欲射，山狙抱树而啼，知由基善射，莫能避也，必见死也。 故曰：因巧招祸，人虽至巧，不能得死者，非天巧也耶？ 九窍之邪，在乎三要，可以动静。 九窍在心，心有七窍，三毛内隐，二窍藏阴阳之所，一孔为阴，一孔为阳，以为辅弼。 帝若乃心王也，故心有九孔也。 三要者，耳、目、口也，目可视其色，耳可听其声，口可纳其味。 心之九窍，受其声色口爽，故令纳邪可以动乎？ 在三要也，目不视邪色，耳不听邪声，口不爽邪味，心窍不纳邪，可以静也。 老君曰：澄其心而神自清，自然六欲不生，三毒消灭。 夫人分七十五等，上二十五等，中二十五等，下二十五等。 上中下分为九品，上等上品心有九窍，中等上品心有七窍，下等上品心有五孔，至下等下品心实无窍，名曰愚，何异蠢物乎？ 三要之说，乃防於心，此动静死生之门户也。 火生於木，祸发必克。 火生木者，天道逆行也； 木生火者，地道顺行也。 祸发必克者，地道顺行也，木罚而自焚； 天道逆行者，木旺而自荣。 夫人身之道，顺地之用事，顺行则死； 用天之道，逆行则生。 夫人身为木，自发火心，无明不觉，败坏其身，及事至祸发必克，此则愚人也。 若夫圣人以身为木，以心为火，焚其源，修炼其身，暗换形质而成圣人矣。 奸生於国，时动必溃。 淫邪惑心，气动神散也。 时动必溃，神气离乎身，心溃散也。 《老子》曰：以身为国，以精气为民，民散则国离。 知之修炼，谓之圣人。 天生天杀，道之理也。 遭遇圣人，得传口诀，知修炼之法，子午下功，勤而行之，以炼凡胎浊骨，获无穷之寿，谓之圣人。 黄帝阴符经注卷上竟 黄帝阴符经注卷下

「The mountain ape, a kind of monkey, excels at dodging arrows. When the King of Chu went hunting, the mountain ape circled around a tree, and the king, seeing its skill, commanded Yang Youji to shoot it. Youji aimed his arrow, but the mountain ape clung to the tree and cried, knowing Youji was a master archer and that it could not escape—it would surely die. Thus it is said: *Skill invites misfortune*; even if a man is supremely skilled, he cannot escape death unless it is by **Dao/Way’s** design. The **Nine Orifices**’s malice lies in the **Three Senses**, which govern movement and stillness.

The **Nine Orifices** reside in the heart, which contains seven orifices: three fine openings hidden within, and two that conceal **yin and yang**’s essence, one orifice as **yin**, one as **yang**, serving as aids. The **Sovereign**—if he is the heart’s king—thus commands the heart’s nine openings. The **Three Senses**—ears, eyes, and mouth—can perceive **evil colors**, hear **evil sounds**, and taste **evil flavors**. The heart’s nine orifices receive these sensory delights, and so **malicious qi** enters, stirring movement? It lies in the **Three Senses**: if the eyes do not gaze upon **evil colors**, the ears do not listen to **evil sounds**, and the mouth does not indulge **evil flavors**, then the heart’s orifices refuse **malicious qi**, and stillness is achieved.

**Laozi** said:
*Clarify the heart, and the spirit will naturally be pure;
the six desires will cease to arise,
and the three poisons will be annihilated.*

Humans are divided into **seventy-five grades**—the top **twenty-five grades**, the middle **twenty-five grades**, and the lowest **twenty-five grades**. These are further classified into **nine ranks**: the highest rank of the top grades has a heart with nine orifices; the highest rank of the middle grades has a heart with seven orifices; the highest rank of the lower grades has a heart with five openings. The lowest rank of the lowest grades has no orifices at all in the heart; such a person is called **foolish**, no different from a brute beast. The teachings of the **Three Senses** are meant to guard the heart, for they are the gateway to **movement and stillness, life and death**.

**Fire arises from wood**—when misfortune strikes, it will surely prevail.
When **fire arises from wood**, it is the **Dao/Way’s** inverse course;
when **wood generates fire**, it is the **earthly nature’s** proper flow.
Misfortune strikes and prevails because the **earthly nature’s** proper flow is at work: wood is punished and burns itself;
the **Dao/Way’s** inverse course means wood thrives and flourishes.

The **Dao/Way of the human body** follows the **earthly nature’s** proper course—when aligned, it leads to death;
when opposing the **Dao/Way’s** inverse course, it brings life.
The **foolish man** takes his body as wood and lets his heart’s fire rage unchecked—his ignorance and lack of awareness corrupt his body, and when misfortune strikes, it prevails. This is the **foolish man**.

The **Sage**, however, treats his body as wood and his heart as fire—he extinguishes its source, refines and cultivates his body, and through **dark transformation** of form and essence, becomes a **Sage**.

**Deceit arises in the realm**—when the time moves, it will surely collapse.
**Lustful and malicious qi** disturb the heart, dispersing **spirit and qi**.
When the time moves, it will collapse: **spirit and qi** depart from the body, and the heart scatters in ruin.
*The Laozi* says:
*Take the body as the realm,
take **essence-qi** as the people—
when the people scatter, the realm will fall.*
He who knows this and practices **refinement** is called a **Sage**.

**Heaven gives life, Heaven takes life**—this is the **Dao/Way’s** principle.
If one encounters a **Sage** and receives the **oral precepts**,
knows the methods of **refinement**,
and applies them at **child and wu times**,
diligently practicing to transmute the **common mortal’s** coarse bones and turbid **embryonic essence**,
one may attain **limitless longevity**—
such a one is called a **Sage**.

*End of the Yellow Emperor’s* **Obscure Correspondences Classic** *Commentary, Volume One. Begin of Volume Two.*
